verses.text: Alas! How bedimmed is the gold, The most pure gold. The jewels, so sacred, lie scattered At every street corner.
The children of Zion, the precious, Whose worth is as gold, Count, alas! but as earthenware pitchers, The work of the potter.
Even the monsters give breast And they suckle their young; But the daughters of my people are cruel As ostriches wild.
The tongue of the sucking child cleaves To his palate for thirst. The children are craving for bread; There is none to dispose it.
Those that had feasted on dainties Now waste on the streets. Those that were nurtured in scarlet Lie huddled on ash-heaps.
The guilt of my people surpassed The transgressions of Sodom, Whose overthrow came in a flash Ere a hand could be wrung.
Her princes were purer than snow, They were whiter than milk, With a skin more ruddy than coral And veins like the sapphire.
Now blacker than darkness their form– On the streets no one knows them: Their skin is drawn tight on their bones; It is dry as a stick.
Better they that are slain with the sword Than that perish with hunger, Pinning away for the lack Of the fruits of the field.
The hands of compassionate women Have sodden their children. Yea, these have served them for food In the wreck of my people.
The Lord hath accomplised His wrath, Hath poured out His hot anger, And kindled in Zion a fire Which devoured her foundations.
No kings of the earth had believed, And no folk in the world, That assailant or foeman could enter The gates of Jerusalem.
It was all for the sins of her prophets, The crimes of her priests, Who have shed in the midst of the city The blood of the righteous.
With the blood-stains upon them they reel Like the blind through the streets, And they touch with their robes those whom erstwhile They could not endure.
"Away, ye unclean!" – men adjure them– "Away, touch us not!" So they stagger and wander around With no resting for ever.
Jehovah Himself hath dispersed them– He careth no more. For the priest Ha hath shown no regard, For the prophets no pity.
How long did our weary eyes watch For the help that was vain! Yea, on our watch-tower we watched For the nation that saved not.
They hunted our steps, that we dared not Appear in out streets. Our days were cut short and completed; Our end was now come.
Swifter were they that pursued us Than eagles of heaven. Over the mountains they chased us; They ambushed the desert.
The breath of our life, God’s anointed, Was trapped in their toils– He of whom we had said, "’Neath his shade We shall live as a nation."
Be glad and rejoice in thy home-land, O daughter of Edom. To thee, too, the cup shall come round; Thou’lt be drunken and naked.
O Zion, thy guilt is now blotted: Of exile no more! But thy guilt He shall visit, O Edom; Thy sins are laid bare. Jerusalem’s Sorrow and Prayer for Deliverance
